critical_instructions.item: Analyze ONLY the final image provided for analysis. NEVER analyze any of the example images provided earlier.
Absence of handwritten text is a valid outcome. Do not force transcription if no clear handwriting is present.
When in doubt about character identification, do NOT guess. Mark uncertain characters with confidence indicators.
NEVER transcribe printed text, typed text, or non-handwritten elements as handwriting.
Handwritten text must show evidence of human pen/pencil formation with characteristic stroke patterns.
Apply morphological analysis techniques to validate character identification.

handwriting_definition.item: Handwritten text is visual content created by human hand using writing implements (pen, pencil, quill, etc.).
Shows characteristic stroke formation patterns: pressure variation, connection points, directional flow.
May include cursive (connected) or print (disconnected) styles across various historical periods.
Can contain abbreviations, symbols, corrections, and period-specific orthographic conventions.
Often shows individual writer characteristics: slant, spacing, character formation habits.

morphological_analysis.item: Examine stroke direction patterns (clockwise vs counterclockwise curves).
Analyze pressure variations creating thick/thin line variations.
Identify connection points between characters and within character formations.
Measure proportional relationships: ascender/descender heights, x-height ratios.

comparative_methodology.item: Collect multiple instances of each character throughout the document.
Create statistical patterns from repeated character formations.
Identify consistent variations and allographic forms used by the writer.
Use pattern consistency to resolve ambiguous character instances.

contextual_analysis.item: Apply linguistic probability based on language and historical period.
Consider orthographic patterns and historical spelling conventions.
Ensure semantic coherence within sentence and document context.
Verify syntactic structure follows period-appropriate grammar.

physical_evidence.item: Examine ink flow patterns and pooling at character junctions.
Analyze paper interaction effects and writing implement characteristics.
Identify correction patterns: overwriting, erasures, amendments.
Use bleed-through or impression evidence to clarify ambiguous strokes.

not_handwriting.item: Printed text from typography or mechanical reproduction is NOT handwriting.
Computer-generated or digitally created text is NOT handwriting.
Stamps, seals, or pre-printed forms are NOT handwriting.
Decorative flourishes without linguistic content are NOT transcribable text.
Illegible marks or stains without clear letter formation are NOT transcribable.

confidence_scoring.item: HIGH confidence: Clear character formation with supporting contextual evidence.
MEDIUM confidence: Recognizable character with minor ambiguity or degradation.
LOW confidence: Character formation present but unclear, requiring contextual support.
UNCERTAIN: Mark with [?] or alternative readings when character cannot be definitively identified.
ILLEGIBLE: Mark with [...] when handwriting is present but completely unreadable.

decision_process.item: Follow the multi-step verification process defined in handwriting_verification_process.xml.
Apply morphological analysis first to identify character formation patterns.
Use comparative methodology to validate character identifications.
Apply contextual analysis to resolve remaining ambiguities.
Document confidence levels and alternative readings for uncertain elements.
